abstract.text: Following the recent report of a furin-like cleavage site unique to SARS-CoV-2, we characterized 23 additional amino acid residues, positioned within the crown of the spike (S) glycoprotein, under 24 diversifying selection along the ancestral lineage of currently circulating pandemic strains, and 25 affecting enhanced ability to infect host cells. Molecular dynamic simulations revealed long-26 range covariant movements of SARS-CoV-2 S glycoprotein monomer in pre-fusion conformation 27 with furin cleavage, and residue T333, under purifying selection, hinge of such movement.

Main -With a toll of confirmed cases rapidly increasing globally, the COVID-19 pandemic is likely 36 to meet the millions in matter of weeks. One of the features that may explain why this novel 37 betacoronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) has been successfully spreading around the globe, is the newly 38 acquired furin-like cleavage site 1 . Furin is ubiquitously expressed at different levels in all 39 tissues 2,3 . However, kinetics of furin-like enzyme activity are different among species -e. g. Table   53   S1 ). Before diving into the new features, we define major domains of SARS-CoV-2 S 54 glycoprotein, based on the available SARS-CoV-1 structure 5 : S1 subunit, that binds to the 55 receptor on the host cell surface 6 , and S2 subunit which plays a role in membrane fusion 7 . In 56 particular, S1 is composed of an N-terminal domain (NTD, residues 14-294) and three C-terminal (Figure 1 ). The S2 subunit is located downstream of S1 66 after the S1/S2 cleavage site (residue 667 for SARS-CoV and residue 660 for SARS-CoV-2). The 67 majority of the residues that differentiate human S glycoproteins from bat or pangolin were found 68 within the S1 subunit ( Figure 1a ). The S glycoprotein was under strong negative/purifying 69 selection with 775 out of 1273 sites were under negative/purifying selection (Table S3) , which 70 suggests the protein has reached a peak on the fitness landscape in terms of structure, stability 71 and folding 11 . We carried out a 90 ns-long simulation to assess the stability of the trimeric 92 structure of SARS-CoV-2 and whether the new gained favorable furin-like cleavage site alters the 93 overall structure of the S glycoprotein.

As recently reported 14 , the CTD1 domain of SARS-CoV-2 S glycoprotein for the pre-fusion 95 conformation rotates outward from center of the triangular head to an "up" position, while this 96 conformation for SARS-CoV is "down" 5 ( Figure 1f ). One monomer of the SARS-CoV-2 S 97 glycoprotein, in fact, acquired the ability of being already in a pre-fusion conformation pointing the 98 ACE2 binding site in a different angle than its predecessor, thus giving SARS-CoV-2 99 advantageous ability to bind and enter into the cell. FIGREF6.text: origin of SARS-CoV-2 lineage: recombination 120 While the origin of this virus strain remains unknown, numerous scenarios have been 121 proposed 1,16,17 . Recombination is an important factor driving viral diversity 18,19 , and has been 122 reported as a possible mechanism favoring cross-species transmission of CoV and increasing its 123 adaptability to a new host 20,21 . Recombination was a critical factor in the emergence of Middle 124 East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in 2012 from bat reservoirs 22,23 . There is 125 currently conflicting evidence on whether or not the new coronavirus originated from 126 recombination events 24-26 . Since the human lineages is 96% identical to bat-SARS-CoV-2 1 , but 127 ACE2 binding residues F486, Q493, S494 and N501 (Figure 1a) are conserved between 128 pangolin-SARS-CoV-2 lineage b strains, we investigated the evolutionary relationships among 129 available full genome sequences (bat and pangolin-related SARS-CoV-2 strains, bat-SL-CoVs,

NNets 131 have the advantage over phylogeny inference algorithms of allowing internal nodes to be 132 cyclically connected (nets) to represent the presence of conflicting phylogenetic signal in the data 133 (i.e. data support for different tree topologies), as in fact we found in the analysis of the 134 coronavirus genomes(Fig. 2a). Of course, conflicting phylogenetic signal in the data is not 135 sufficient to infer recombination 28 . To test whether the NNet topology is due to recombination we 136 used the pairwise homoplasy index (PHI) test 29 , which detected highly significant signal for 137 recombination (p < 10 -99 ) among all included strains(Figure 1a). FIGREF10.text: potential recombination hotspots. Seven of them were found in the polyprotein 173 segment (Figure 2b), which spans three quarters of the viral RNA; the remaining two involved 174 protein E, orf8, and protein N. It has been reported that the orf8 gene plays a role in regulating 175 the viral replication in the host cell 31 , and was probably acquired by the whole lineage of SARS-176 CoV-1 from the SARS-related CoV from Greater Horseshoe bats (SARSr-Rf-BatCoVs) following 177 a recombination event with a Chinese horseshoe bat coronavirus (SARSr-Rs-BatCoV) 32 . A 178 second analysis, with a sliding window of size 200, detected two recombination coldspots on the 179 N terminal region of the glycoprotein (between residues S31 to V47, and Y145 to G184, p ≤0.01) 180 (Figure 2b). Under more relax assumptions (0.01 ≤ p ≤0.05) coldspot region spans from Q14 to 181 S71, and from V127 to T240 (Figure 2b). Residues S32F, A112S, N519H (Figure 1) are outside 182 the coldspot region, however L50S is inside the first coldspot region of SARS-CoV-2 S 183 glycoprotein. Our finding seems to be in conflict with high recombination rates being found in non-184 human coronaviruses 33 , yet, it is not surprising that part of a gene playing a fundamental role in 185 cell entry and fusion would sit into a recombination coldspot. While the majority of the CoV 186 genome seems prone to recombination, the S glycoprotein is the only one that harbored 187 recombination coldspots. This might depend on functional costraints on specific domains of the 188 protein 34 , or other factors impacting the probability of recombination events, such as RNA 189 secondary structure 35,36 . Another possibility is that the N terminal, under negative selection, 190 reached a peak on the adaptive landscape and new mutations/rearrangements are unlikely to be 191 fixed in the next generations due to negative selection. These findings correlate with mobility of 192 MD simulations, where flexible stretches are less conserved, while hinge regions remained 193 unchanged during evolution of the lineage.

FIGREF12.text: presents two notable changes: a favorable furin-like cleavage site 1 , 200 and CTD1 up in pre-fusion mode 14 . On the contrary S glycoprotein of previously circulating 201 SARS-CoV strains do not have a favorable furin-like cleavage site 1 and remain un-cleaved after 202 biosynthesis 37 . Furin has the potential to cleave specifically viral envelope glycoproteins, to 203 enhance viral fusion with host cell membranes 38 , thereby any variation/mutational changes in 204 amino acid composition at cleavage sites may impact tissue and cell tropism, host range, and 205 pathogenesis 39 , as reported for other respiratory viruses 40-42 . Moreover, our MD simulations 206 correlated furin-like cleavage site correlated with pre-fusion conformation. Simulations indicated 207 that the motion of CTD1 is quite visible and is the most relevant motion in the protein: a 208 conserved region that acts as a hinge in the opening/closing mechanism. We described residue 209 T333, under purifying selection, as the hinge of the rotation movement that gives further 210 advantage to bind cell receptors facilitating fusion and entry. Further analysis will be done to 211 analyze the conformation change of the S glycoprotein and the residues interface in nearly real 212 conditions. Development of inhibitors of such motion may reduce substantially pre-fusion 213 conformation and therefore the infectivity of SARS-CoV-2.

FIGREF15.text: We conclude that SARS-CoV-2 likely emerged from recombination events that involves ancestral 233 strains circulating among bat and pangolin. However, we could not completely distinguish the234 recombinant sequence from the parental ones in other cases. Recombination signal and selective 235 pressures can interfere with each other 44 , with positive selected mutations near potential 236 recombination breakpoints 45 . More extensive sampling of wildlife CoVs would help in clarifying 237 the events that led to the jump to humans. Future emergence of novel recombinant CoVs, and 238 other viruses as well, should be a constant concern; strengthening surveillance of viral 239 populations and improving our understanding of their dynamics will help the prevention of new 240 zoonotic outbreaks and spread of emerging pathogens.
